g.title: leaf_7
g.text: The behavior of abstract syntax trees in `pegylator` is provided by the Node

g.title: leaf_8
g.text: This is in turn poorly specified and full of exploratory code that is in need

g.title: leaf_16
g.text: To be a Node, all indexed elements of the Array must also be Nodes.

g.title: leaf_17
g.text: There are invariant fields a Node is also expected to have, they are:
- `first` : Index into `str` which begins the span.
- `last` : Index into `str` which ends the span.
This is identical to the name of the pattern that recognizes

g.title: leaf_18
g.text: There are other fields which are of less obvious value, which still exist:

g.title: leaf_19
g.text: - `str` : a "string" covering the whole abstract syntax tree.
This is normally found on root for which see:
- `root` : a function which, called, returns the root node.
I was impressed with this idea when I came up with it.
Haven't been getting much use out of it.

g.title: leaf_20
g.text: An important optional field, if a Node has a semantic span (such as a symbol)

g.title: leaf_21
g.text: - `val` : The substring of value to the syntax tree.

g.title: leaf_27
g.text: This is currently constructed wildly and piecemeal. It also does important

g.title: leaf_32
g.text: Some of my most recent code, this prints the AST as a dot file.

g.title: leaf_33
g.text: It is now reasonably documented in [[src/peg/transform.lua]].

g.title: leaf_36
g.text: Select pulls out sub Nodes which fulfill certain predicates.
